title: 107_s1196
content: The "Small Business Investment Company Amendments Act of 2001" amends subsidy fees and conflicts of interest in the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. Subsidy fees are adjusted to not exceed 1.38 percent per year, effective October 1, 2001. Conflicts of interest disclosure requirements are modified. SEC. 3. CONFLICTS OF INTEREST amended by removing disclosure requirement in the locality most directly affected by the transaction. SEC. 4. PENALTIES FOR FALSE STATEMENTS. SEC. 4. PENALTIES FOR FALSE STATEMENTS. Amends criminal and civil penalties related to false statements in connection with small business investment companies and the Small Business Administration. SEC. 5. REMOVAL OR SUSPENSION OF MANAGEMENT OFFICIALS. Amends the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 to define 'management official' and outline the process for removal based on willful violations. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 defines a 'management official' and outlines the process for their removal based on willful violations of fiduciary duties involving personal dishonesty. The notice of intention to remove a management official must state the grounds and schedule a hearing within 30 to 60 days. The Administrator may set a hearing date within 30-60 days, with exceptions for earlier or later dates upon request. Failure to appear at the hearing implies consent to removal. If grounds for removal are established, the Administrator can issue an order of removal effective after 30 days. The Administrator may issue orders of removal from office if grounds are established, which become effective after 30 days. The Administrator also has the authority to suspend or prohibit participation in management for protection of the licensee or Administration's interests. The Administrator has the authority to suspend or prohibit management officials for protection of the licensee or Administration's interests. This action becomes effective upon notice and remains in effect until administrative proceedings are completed or charges are dismissed. The Administrator can suspend or prohibit management officials to protect the licensee or Administration's interests. This action remains in effect until administrative proceedings are completed or charges are dismissed. Management officials can seek judicial review within 10 days of suspension or prohibition. The Administrator can suspend or prohibit management officials charged with felonies involving dishonesty or breach of trust. The United States District Court for the District of Columbia can grant a stay of the suspension pending administrative proceedings. The Administrator has the authority to suspend or prohibit management officials charged with felonies involving dishonesty or breach of trust. The suspension or prohibition remains in effect until the case is resolved, and upon conviction, the Administrator can issue an order for the removal of the management official. The Administrator can suspend or remove management officials charged with felonies involving dishonesty or breach of trust. The removal becomes effective upon serving the order to the licensee. A finding of not guilty does not prevent further proceedings to suspend or remove the official. Notices served to management officials must also be served to the licensee. Hearings are held in the district where the licensee's principal office is located unless agreed otherwise. After a hearing, the Administrator must issue a decision within 90 days and serve orders to all parties involved. The Administrator has the authority to modify or terminate orders at any time. The Administrator has the authority to modify, terminate, or set aside any order issued under this section at any time, with judicial review exclusively as provided in this subsection. Any party to a hearing under this section may seek review of an order by filing a petition in the court of appeals within 30 days. The Administrator must be notified, and the record of the proceeding will be filed in the court. Upon filing a petition in the court of appeals within 30 days, the Administrator is notified, and the court gains exclusive jurisdiction to affirm, modify, terminate, or set aside the Administrator's order. The court's judgment is final but subject to review by the Supreme Court. The court of appeals gains exclusive jurisdiction upon filing a petition within 30 days. The court's judgment is final but subject to review by the Supreme Court. Proceedings for judicial review do not automatically stay any order issued by the Administrator. SEC. 6. REDUCTION OF FEES. SEC. 6. REDUCTION OF FEES. (a) Two-Year Reduction of Section 7(a) Fees.-- Guarantee fees for loans approved during a 2-year period starting on October 1, 2002, will have reduced rates based on the total loan amount. The guarantee fee percentages vary depending on the loan amount ranges. Annual fees for loans approved during the same 2-year period will also be adjusted. During a 2-year period starting on October 1, 2002, annual fees for loans approved will be adjusted. The annual fee will be 0.25 percent of the outstanding balance of the deferred participation share of the loan. Additionally, fees for Section 504 loans will not exceed 50 percent of the amount established under clause (i) for loans made during the same 2-year period. During a 2-year period starting on October 1, 2002, fees for Section 504 loans will not exceed 50 percent of the amount established for loans made during the same period. Additionally, the Small Business Administration may not assess or collect any up front guarantee fee for loans made under this title during the 2-year period. During the 2-year period starting on October 1, 2002, the Small Business Administration will treat financings under specific acts as separate programs for Federal Credit Reform purposes. The amendments to the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 will only be effective if funds are available under appropriations Acts to offset the costs. These changes will come into effect on October 1, 2002.
